qas.question: What types of script was used to write Sanskrit in the northwest part of Indai?
Around what time did the Gupta script become prevalent for writing Sanskrit?

answers.text: between the fourth and eighth centuries

qas.question: Which script evolved from the Gupta script in the 8th century?
Which script replaced the Gupta script?
In what time period did the Devangari script become prevalent?
What were used to write Sanskrit?
What script was used in the northwest of India?
Between the forth and eighth century, what script evolved?
What script evolved from the Gupta script?
What script was used in the northeast?

plausible_answers.text: between the fourth and eighth centuries

qas.question: In what centuries were the Brahmic scripts used?
What was the Brahmi script derived from?
What script was the Devanagari script replace with in the 12th century?
What alphabet was mainly used in West India?

context: Brahmi evolved into a multiplicity of <a5_0>Brahmic scripts<a5_0/>, many of which were used to write Sanskrit. Roughly contemporary with the Brahmi, <a0_0><a6_0><b10_0>Kharosthi<b10_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/> was used in the northwest of the subcontinent. Sometime <a1_0><b11_0>between the fourth and eighth centuries<b11_0/><a1_0/>, <b12_0>the <a7_0>Gupta<a7_0/> script<b12_0/>, derived from <a8_0>Brahmi<a8_0/>, became prevalent. Around the eighth century, the <a2_0><a9_0>Śāradā<a9_0/><a2_0/> script evolved out of the <b13_0>Gupta script<b13_0/>. The latter was displaced in its turn by <a3_0>Devanagari<a3_0/> in the <a4_0>11th or 12th century<a4_0/>, with intermediary stages such as the Siddhaṃ script. In East India, <b14_0>the Bengali alphabet<b14_0/>, and, later, the Odia alphabet, were used.
